post_text: Hello NSSD families and staff, we've just activated a new Facebook page called NSSD Wildfire Community Support. We created it in hopes it will provide a public forum to allow our families and staff to post any immediate needs they have as a result of being displaced due to the wildfires. We've seen so many posts from people anxious to help but not sure how. Hopefully this will connect these generous folks with the people who are in desperate need. PLEASE SHARE!
shared_text:
NSSD Wildfire Community Support
September 11 at 3:16 AM ·

This page has been created as public space to allow families and staff from the North Santiam School District to post any immediate needs they may have as a result of being displaced due to the wildfires in order to allow our amazing community to offer direct assistance. This will be ongoing and is a resource in addition to the clothing drive being organized by SHS staff for Sept 15. It is our hope this can make connections possible for those who need immediate help. Intial plans are to have recipients and the folks providing items to connect directly for the exchange in a safe place. Please use caution when making deliveries and practice all COVID-related safety protocols. We will do our best to monitor the discussions but if you see anything concerning, please send a direct message. The District is providing this venue for the public to communicate and ask that all comments be respectful and remain focused on the purpose at hand. Any other types of comments will be removed.

#14 – Riley Hodges: Persistent Optimism in the Face of Adversity — Santiam Local

Santiam Local
June 9 at 6:02 PM ·

Episode 14 is up!🎙
Stayton High School graduating senior Riley Hodges shares his story optimism in the face of adversity. Even in his darkest times when Riley contemplated whether life was worth living, he found the will and desire for a better life: “I want to be the best me I can be,” he says. His move to Lyons, Oregon and transfer to Stayton High was a positive life choice.
Riley made huge strides academically, he got involved in everything from football, track and field, to theater and tutoring. After the unexpected death of his uncle during his senior year, Riley had several life-changing moments, including receiving the news that he’d been awarded a four-year scholarship through the The Ford Family Foundation's Ford Scholars Program. 🏆🌟

Join us at the Stayton Library
February 18 at 8:14 PM ·

Call for Artists of All Ages for Summer Reading Art Contest

The Stayton Public Library is announcing a call for artwork for the 2020 Summer Reading Program. Submitted artwork should be inspired by the Summer Reading Theme, “Imagine Your Story”, which highlights fairytales, mythology, and fantasy.

Any artists that live, attend school, or work in Stayton or its surrounding communities can submit a design. There will be three categories based on the artist’s age: Kids, Teens, and Adults. The winner in each category will have their artwork featured on Stayton Public Library’s Summer Reading materials both in print and online and win a $25 Amazon gift card.

Art can be submitted online at staytonlibrary.org or in person at Stayton Public Library, 515 N. 1st Ave, Stayton, and must be received no later than 5:00 p.m. on March 31, 2020. Winners will be announced in May.

For more information and official rules, visit http://www.staytonoregon.gov/page/library_srp_art

Sarah will experience an intensive five-day academic enrichment program for high-achieving high school and middle school students. Only 1% of middle school students who apply for the program are accepted. Sarah is excited to learn more about coding while there and has a strong interest in computers and technology.

Katelyn and Sarah, you are inspiring!

Our Town / Santiam
March 17, 2019 at 5:20 AM ·

Highlights on top again

By James Day

The Stayton Highlights are OSAA dance and drill champions again!
The Highlights captured their 14th state title in 19 years Saturday night at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum, claiming the Class 4A-3A-2A-1A title with a score of 91.48.
Stayton’s score was the top one of the competition regardless of class. The Highlights also turned in the largest margin of victory, as Valley Catholic finished approximately 5.5 points back at 85.92.
Tigard (86.63) won the Class 6A competition, Pendleton (79.98) won in Class 5A (79.98) and Canby (88.27) was tops in the Show division.
Since 2001 Stayton has won 14 state titles, including 12 in a row from 2003-2014. The Highlights, coached by Robin Meier, also have been runners-up 5 times during that period.
The title is the squad’s first since 2017, when they also won the Class 4A-1A competition. Last season the Highlights finished runners-up to Canby in Show.

post_text: Let's all wear pink for STAND UP to Bullying Day this Friday, Feb 22! The day emerged in 2008 from the acts of two Nova Scotian 12th graders, Travis Price and David Shepherd, who stood up when a fellow student was being bullied for wearing a pink shirt. They bought 50 pink shirts asked classmates to wear them the following day to create a "sea of pink" to support the bullied student. Many students wore the shirts, and many others came in their own pink clothes. Their act of creativity and kindness gained notice around the world and by the following year, International STAND UP to Bullying Day was created. It is observed on the last Friday of every February and the third Friday every November.

NSSD school board members, Tass Morrison and Garrett Trott, along with Superintendent Gardner lead by example when it comes to being lifelong learners! They recently attended the annual OSBA (Oregon School Boards Assoc) conference where sessions were offered on topics like chronic absenteeism, equity and inclusion and strategies for meeting the social and emotional needs of students - just to name a few!

Because the dynamic and forward-thinking habits of the NSSD Board have caught the attention of OSBA in the past, their Board Secretary, Tonia Whisman, was asked to participate on a panel at the conference. She collaborated with others in sharing positive insight into the inner-workings of their boards and how they relate to their secretaries.

November 29, 2018 at 6:59 PM ·

OSBA Officers met with Governor Kate Brown this morning to continue discussing the recommended 2019-21 budget and impacts on Oregon education.

The governor offered two budget approaches Wednesday: an education status-quo budget based on current revenue and an investment budget that adds nearly $1.3 billion for early learning and K-12 education with as-yet-unnamed revenue.
